Product Overview\n\nAn interactive, educational, and tool-driven rotary engine website focused initially on the Mazda 13B-style rotary engine. It runs as a Blazor WebAssembly app and explains how rotary engines work through visualizations, simulations, and data-driven insights for enthusiasts, students, and builders.\n\nPhysics and predictions are illustrative and educational only, not manufacturer-certified.\n\n## 2. Target Users\n\n- **Enthusiasts**\n  - Car and rotary fans wanting intuitive visual explanations.\n- **Students / Learners**\n  - Engineering and tech students needing conceptual understanding of rotary operation.\n- **Builders / Tuners (entry–mid level)**\n  - Hobbyists exploring effects of tuning parameters on wear, heat, and risk.\n\n## 3. Core Product Goals\n\n- Explain rotary (13B) operation with clear, accessible visuals and language.\n- Allow users to manipulate key engine parameters and immediately see effects.\n- Present risks (wear, heat, detonation risk) in a simple, intuitive way.\n- Provide a foundation that can later extend to other engines (20B, Renesis) and deeper simulations.\n\n## 4. Key Features\n\n### 4.1 Educational Content & Visuals\n\n- Overview of rotary engine parts and operation:\n  - Rotor geometry and motion\n  - Eccentric shaft operation\n  - Intake, compression, combustion, exhaust cycles\n  - Apex, side, and corner seals\n- Clear, user-friendly explanations derived from engineering concepts.\n- Glossary of rotary-specific terminology.\n\n### 4.2 Interactive Engine Visualization\n\n- 2D or 3D visualization of a 13B-style rotary engine:\n  - Animated rotor movement inside housing.\n  - Visual indication of cycles (color or labels for intake, compression, combustion, exhaust).\n- Overlays for:\n  - Heat distribution / thermal stress zones.\n  - Wear “intensity” or risk over time (apex seal, etc.).\n- Ability to pause, slow down, and step through cycles.\n\n### 4.3 Simulation Inputs\n\nUser-adjustable parameters (via UI controls):\n\n- Boost pressure\n- Air–fuel ratio (AFR)\n- Ignition timing\n- RPM range / operating profile\n- Seal type/material (e.g., OEM, upgraded, “race”)\n\n### 4.4 Simulation Outputs\n\nReal-time or near-real-time outputs, based on simplified physics models from the Research Agent:\n\n- Predicted wear levels (especially apex seals, but can include general wear metric).\n- Thermal stress / temperature zones.\n- Simple risk classification:\n  - “Safe”\n  - “Aggressive”\n  - “Engine-grenade” (or equivalent high-risk label)\n- Visualization responds dynamically as inputs change.\n\n### 4.5 Architecture & Extensibility\n\n- Modular simulation logic:\n  - Encapsulated models for:\n    - Heat behavior\n    - Wear behavior\n    - Stress/risk computation\n  - Engine configuration profiles (start with 13B, but structure allows adding 20B, Renesis later).\n- Clear separation between:\n  - UI components\n  - Visualization/graphics module\n  - Simulation/calculation logic\n- Structured API-style boundaries within the Blazor app (e.g., services, model classes) for possible future use by mobile apps or advanced analytics.\n\n### 4.6 Quality, Usability & Performance\n\n- Simple and intuitive UI for non-engineers:\n  - Clear labels and tooltips\n  - Use of colors and graphics instead of dense text\n- Performance:\n  - Smooth animations on modern browsers\n  - Reasonable CPU usage for WebAssembly in typical desktop/laptop environments\n- Robustness:\n  - Graceful handling of invalid or extreme input values\n  - Clear warnings that output is illustrative/approximate\n\n## 5. Technical Constraints & Environment\n\n- **Framework:** Blazor WebAssembly.\n- **Project structure:**\n  - Use the existing `app/` folder as the Blazor project root.\n  - Do NOT create separate `frontend/` or `backend/` folders for the app UI.\n- **Code locations:**\n  - Main configuration: `app/Program.cs`\n  - Pages/views: `app/Pages/*`\n  - Static assets (images, JS helpers, CSS): `app/wwwroot/*`\n- **Backend:**\n  - Primarily client-side (WASM). Only add server/backend services if absolutely necessary; keep any such boundary clean and minimal.\n- **Local run instructions:**\n  - Must support: `cd app && dotnet run`\n- **Deliverables required in project root (not inside app/):**\n  - `README.md` – Setup and run instructions, including:\n    - Summary of where Blazor frontend (and any backend) live.\n    - How to start the app locally.\n  - `logs/CHANGELOG.md` – Updated with at least one summary line for this run.\n- **Licensing / Data constraints:**\n  - Use publicly available, generic specs; avoid manufacturer-protected or proprietary data.\n  - Emphasize educational nature of predictions; no claim of OEM endorsement or certification.\n\n## 6. Content & Simulation Requirements\n\n### 6.1 Research & Content\n\n- Create a rotary engine knowledge base (markdown or JSON) that covers:\n  - 13B basics, rotor geometry, seal types, cycles, common failure modes.\n  - Public specs: approximate rotor dimensions, compression ratios, typical RPM limits, etc.\n- Simplified math/logic models (not full CFD/FEA) for:\n  - Wear progression (focus on apex seals).\n  - Heat buildup and dissipation.\n  - Stress indicators relevant to tuning changes.\n- Validation notes:\n  - Clear documentation of simplifying assumptions.\n  - Ranges where model is “reasonable” vs “very approximate.”\n\n### 6.2 Simulation Logic\n\n- Deterministic functions that input:\n  - RPM profile, boost, AFR, timing, seal choice.\n- And output:\n  - Normalized wear index (0–1 or 0–100 scale).\n  - Normalized heat index.\n  - Risk category derived from thresholds on these indices.\n- Ensure:\n  - Functions are fast enough for user-interactive updates.\n  - Edge cases (extreme values) produce safe, bounded outputs and warnings.\n\n## 7. Non-Goals / Out of Scope (for this phase)\n\n- Exact OEM-accurate performance prediction or tuning guidance.\n- Multi-engine comparison tools beyond basic architecture support.\n- Deep builder tools (e.g., full tune maps, part selection optimization).\n- Production deployment infrastructure; focus is on local run and demo-level quality.\n\nAGENT_TASKS.md:\n# AGENT TASKS – Rotary Engine Website (Blazor WASM)\n\nProject Name: **Rotary Engine Interactive Simulator (13B Focus)**\n\nCommon Required Deliverables (Project Root unless noted):\n- `README.md` – Setup and run instructions; explain that Blazor app lives in `app/`, how to run (`cd app && dotnet run`), and where frontend/simulation logic reside.\n- `logs/CHANGELOG.md` – Updated with at least one summary line for this run.\n- Blazor app code and assets under `app/`, including:\n  - `app/Program.cs`\n  - `app/Pages/*`\n  - `app/wwwroot/*`\n- Internal knowledge/document files as chosen formats (e.g., markdown or JSON) stored under an appropriate folder inside `app/` (e.g., `app/Data/` or similar).\n\n---\n\n## 1. Design Goals\n---------------\n\n- Make rotary engine concepts visually intuitive for non-engineers.\n- Allow “playful tinkering” with parameters while clearly surfacing risk.\n- Keep mental load low: simple navigation, short labels, strong visual hierarchy.\n- Respect technical constraints:\n  - Blazor WebAssembly, single-page app feel with multiple routed pages.\n  - Visualization implementable via SVG/Canvas/WebGL with optional JS interop.\n\n2. Information Architecture\n---------------------------\n\n### 2.1 Primary Navigation (Top App Bar)\n\n- **Logo/Title**: “Rotary Engine Simulator”\n- **Nav links** (left-to-right):\n  - Home\n  - Engine Overview\n  - Simulation\n  - Glossary\n  - About & Disclaimers\n- **Theme / speed control (right side)**:\n  - Animation speed selector (for visualizer) or simple slider.\n  - Optional light/dark toggle (future; not required in first pass).\n\n### 2.2 Pages\n\n1. **Home (Index)**  \n   - High-level intro and “Call to Explore” buttons.\n2. **Engine Overview**  \n   - Educational content with static/low-interaction diagrams.\n3. **Simulation**  \n   - Core interactive area: parameter inputs + visualization + outputs.\n4. **Glossary**  \n   - Searchable list of terms.\n5. **About & Disclaimers**  \n   - Educational nature, model limitations, credits.\n\n3. Global Layout & Visual Style\n-------------------------------\n\n### 3.1 Layout Structure\n\n- **Top App Bar** (persistent on all pages)\n  - 60–72px height.\n  - Contains title, navigation links, and small controls.\n- **Content Area**\n  - Centered, max-width ~1200–1320px on large screens.\n  - Padding: 16–24px.\n- **Footer** (persistent)\n  - Short disclaimer summary.\n  - Link to full About & Disclaimers page.\n\n### 3.2 Visual Design\n\n- **Color Palette (suggested)**\n  - Background: Light gray off-white (`#F5F5F7`) or white.\n  - Primary accent: Deep blue (`#1F4F7B`) for headers and CTAs.\n  - Secondary accent: Warm orange/red (`#E86F3E`) for combustion / high heat indicators.\n  - Safe indicators: Green (`#24A148`).\n  - Warning indicators: Amber (`#F1C21B`).\n  - Danger indicators: Red (`#DA1E28`).\n- **Typography**\n  - Headings: Sans-serif, larger weights for hierarchy (e.g., 600).\n  - Body: Clear sans-serif; avoid dense paragraphs.\n  - Use consistent heading levels `h1–h4` to structure content.\n- **Iconography**\n  - Simple line icons (question mark for help, “i” for info, flame for heat, wrench for wear).\n- **Visual Language**\n  - Use colors & simple shapes (triangles, epitrochoid housing outline) to explain ideas.\n  - Avoid overly realistic “car culture” imagery; prioritize diagrams over photos.\n\n### 3.3 Responsiveness\n\n- **Desktop (≥1024px)**\n  - Simulation page: 2–3 column layout (Controls | Visualizer | Outputs).\n- **Tablet (768–1023px)**\n  - Two-column stacked: Controls (top/left) and Visualizer/Outputs (right/bottom).\n- **Mobile (<768px)**\n  - Single column vertical order:\n    1. Visualizer\n    2. Outputs\n    3. Controls\n    4. Explanations/help\n\n4. Page-Level Designs\n---------------------\n\n### 4.1 Home Page (Index)\n\n**Purpose**: Introduce the app, guide users to Overview or Simulation.\n\n**Content & Sections**\n\n1. **Hero Section**\n   - Left:\n     - Title: “Explore the 13B Rotary Engine”\n     - Short subtitle: “See how a rotary engine breathes, burns, and wears as you tune it.”\n     - Primary CTA button: “Start Simulation”\n     - Secondary CTA: “Learn the Basics”\n   - Right:\n     - Static stylized rotor + housing illustration (image asset).\n     - Optional micro-animation (CSS-based) if cheap to implement.\n\n2. **How It Works (Three Columns)**\n   - Three bullets:\n     - Enthusiasts\n     - Students\n     - Builders/Tuners\n   - Very short, approachable text.\n\n4. **Educational Disclaimer Snippet**\n   - Brief sentence: “This tool is for learning, not for tuning your real engine.”\n   - Left/Top: Subheading + short explanatory text.\n  - Right/Bottom: Static diagram or simplified illustration.\n\n**Key Sections**\n\n1. **What Is a Rotary (Wankel) Engine?**\n   - High-level description.\n2. **Major Components**\n   - It runs as a Blazor WebAssembly app and explains how rotary engines work through visualizations, simulations, and data-driven insights for enthusiasts, students, and builders.\n\nPhysics and predictions are illustrative and educational only, not manufacturer-certified.\n\n## 2. Target Users\n\n- **Enthusiasts**\n  - Car and rotary fans wanting intuitive visual explanations.\n- **Students / Learners**\n  - Engineering and tech students needing conceptual understanding of rotary operation.\n- **Builders / Tuners (entry–mid level)**\n  - Hobbyists exploring effects of tuning parameters on wear, heat, and risk.\n\n## 3. Core Product Goals\n\n- Explain rotary (13B) operation with clear, accessible visuals and language.\n- Allow users to manipulate key engine parameters and immediately see effects.\n- Present risks (wear, heat, detonation risk) in a simple, intuitive way.\n- Provide a foundation that can later extend to other engines (20B, Renesis) and deeper simulations.\n\n## 4. Key Features\n\n### 4.1 Educational Content & Visuals\n\n- Overview of rotary engine parts and operation:\n  - Rotor geometry and motion\n  - Eccentric shaft operation\n  - Intake, compression, combustion, exhaust cycles\n  - Apex, side, and corner seals\n- Clear, user-friendly explanations derived from engineering concepts.\n- Glossary of rotary-specific terminology.\n\n### 4.2 Interactive Engine Visualization\n\n- 2D or 3D visualization of a 13B-style rotary engine:\n  - Animated rotor movement inside housing.\n  - Visual indication of cycles (color or labels for intake, compression, combustion, exhaust).\n- Overlays for:\n  - Heat distribution / thermal stress zones.\n  - Goals & Deliverables\n\n### 2.1 Goals\n- Introduce standard top-level directories:\n  - `/docs`\n  - `/agents`\n  - `/tasks`\n  - `/logs`\n  - `/db`\n- Align the agent/roster structure with the existing “rotary builder” project conventions.\n- Provide clear setup and run instructions via a root `README.md`.\n- Record this retrofit in `logs/CHANGELOG.md` with a summary line for this run.\n- Ensure the Blazor WebAssembly app continues to build and run successfully using `dotnet run` from the `app/` directory.\n\n### 2.2 Required Artifacts\n- `README.md` (project root)\n  - Clear instructions to set up and run the Blazor WASM app locally.\n  - Must explicitly mention running from `app/` via `dotnet run`.\n- `logs/CHANGELOG.md`\n  - Updated with a new summary line describing this EPIC 00 retrofit run (date, short description).\n- Directory structure:\n  - `/docs/` – Documentation and high-level design notes.\n  - `/agents/` – Definitions, configurations, and rosters for agents.\n  - `/tasks/` – Task specifications, EPICs, and work items (including `EPIC_00_MVP.md`).\n  - `/logs/` – Changelogs and process logs (including `logs/CHANGELOG.md`).\n  - `/db/` – Database-related assets (migrations, schemas, mock data, etc., as applicable).\n- Blazor app updates within `app/`:\n  - Keep all UI and WebAssembly app code under `app/`.\n  - May update:\n    - `app/Program.cs`\n    - `app/Pages/*`\n    - `app/wwwroot/*`\n  - Must not introduce separate `frontend/` or `backend/` folders for the app UI.\n\n## 3. Integrate this with the existing Blazor WebAssembly app (in `app/`) so the data model and completion logic can be exercised locally.\n\n## Target Users\n- Internal developers and data engineers defining engine build logic.\n- QA/testers validating build-completion behavior.\n- Future UI engineers who will surface build completion status in the Blazor app.\n\n## Key Functional Requirements\n\n### 1. Database Schema\nCreate initial MySQL schema and migrations to support build completion logic.\n\nDeliverable: `db/migrations/001_init.sql`\n\nMust define (at minimum) tables:\n\n- **Category**\n  - Represents conceptual groupings (e.g., apex seals, side seals, coolant seals, etc.).\n  - Supports multiple trees (e.g., "core").\n\n- **CategoryTree**\n  - Defines logical trees (e.g., “core”) for organizing categories.\n\n- **CategoryEdge**\n  - Supports hierarchical/category graph relationships within a tree.\n\n- **EngineFamily**\n  - Example: `13B-REW` with `rotor_count=2`.\n  - Must support formula-based requirements (e.g., requirements referencing `rotor_count`).\n\n- **CategoryRequirement**\n  - Links `EngineFamily` to `Category` with formula rules for required quantities.\n  - Must support formula like `3 * rotor_count` for apex seals.\n  - Formulas must be evaluable within SQL or via a well-defined approach (e.g., simple arithmetic expressions over known engine attributes).\n\n- **Part**\n  - Master list of parts (individual pieces and kits).\n  - Must distinguish between atomic parts and kits (BOM-based).\n\n- **PartCategory**\n  - Associates parts with one or more categories (for completion aggregation).\n\n- **PartComponent**\n  - Defines BOM relationships (kit → component parts and quantities).\n  - Must allow kits that expand into multiple underlying parts across categories.\n\n- **Vendor**\n  - Represents suppliers for parts.\n\n- **PartOffering**\n  - Vendor-specific offerings of parts, with pricing/availability fields (at least stubbed).\n\n- **Build**\n  - Represents a specific engine build instance for a given engine family.\n\n- **BuildSelection**\n  - User-selected parts (including kits) associated with a build.\n  - Must allow quantity per selected part.\n\n### 2. Seed Data\nDeliverable: `db/seeds/seed_minimal.sql`\n\nSeed a minimal but non-trivial dataset that demonstrates completion logic:\n\n- At least one **EngineFamily**: `13B-REW` with `rotor_count=2`.\n- At least one **CategoryTree**: `"core"`.\n- Categories including at least:\n  - apex seals\n  - side seals\n  - coolant seals\n  - additional related categories as needed.\n- **CategoryRequirement** entries:\n  - Formula-based quantity requirements using engine family attributes.\n  - Example: `apex_seals_required = 3 * rotor_count` for `13B-REW`.\n- At least 30 **Part** records across categories.\n  - Include both individual parts and kits.\n- At least 2 **kits** that expand via **PartComponent** (BOM) into multiple components.\n  - Kits must meaningfully affect completion counts when expanded.\n- At least one **Build** linked to `13B-REW` with **BuildSelection** rows that:\n  - Demonstrate fully complete, partially complete, and under-supplied scenarios per category.\n\n### 3. Completion Query\nDeliverables:\n- Implementation within schema/SQL as a view or representative query (documented in `docs/DATA_MODEL.md`).\n- Test coverage in `TEST.md` for correctness.\n\nRequirements:\n\n- Must compute, for a given build:\n  - Required count per category:\n    - Use engine-specific category requirements.\n    - Interpret formulas (e.g., `3 * rotor_count`) correctly.\n  - Supplied pieces per category:\n    - Expand kits into their component parts using `PartComponent`.\n    - Aggregate quantities across direct parts and kit components.\n  - Compare required vs supplied:\n    - Determine a per-category status:\n      - `complete` (supplied ≥ required)\n      - `partial` (0 < supplied < required)\n      - `missing` (supplied = 0 but required > 0)\n    - Compute progress metric per category (e.g., `supplied / required`, capped at 1.0).\n  - Provide an overall build status/progress summary (e.g., based on worst category or aggregate).\n\n- The completion query must be:\n  - Deterministic and repeatable from seed data.\n  - Usable in automated tests (no reliance on non-seeded rows).\n\n### 4. Conceptual Data Model\n\nThis section defines semantics only. Backend will translate this into exact MySQL column definitions in `db/migrations/001_init.sql`. Names here should match final schema.\n\n### 1.1 Category Trees & Hierarchy\n\n**CategoryTree**  \nRepresents a named classification tree.\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `name` – e.g., `"core"`.\n- `description` – optional, human-readable purpose.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- A tree defines a logical grouping of categories. For EPIC 01, at least `"core"` is required, which covers the core components needed to assess build completeness (apex seals, side seals, coolant seals, etc.).\n- Future trees might exist for other business views (e.g., “cooling system”, “oil system”).\n\n---\n\n**Category**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `tree_id` – FK → `CategoryTree.id`.\n- `name` – human-readable, e.g., `"apex seals"`, `"side seals"`.\n- `code` – short unique identifier within a tree, e.g., `APEX_SEAL`, `SIDE_SEAL`.\n- `description` – optional.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Categories are conceptual groups of parts that are evaluated as a unit for completion.\n- A part can map to multiple categories (via `PartCategory`), but for EPIC 01 we will typically have a 1:1 or a small number of mappings.\n- Category instances are always scoped to a tree (e.g., `"core"`).\n\n---\n\n**CategoryEdge**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `tree_id` – FK → `CategoryTree.id`.\n- `parent_category_id` – FK → `Category.id`.\n- `child_category_id` – FK → `Category.id`.\n- Optional fields (if needed in migration):\n  - `sort_order` – to define UI ordering.\n  - `relationship_type` – e.g., `"contains"`, `"depends_on"` (for future use).\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Defines hierarchical or graph relationships between categories within a single `CategoryTree`.\n- For EPIC 01, hierarchy is mostly informational; completion logic can treat each category independently. However, edges may be useful in future for:\n  - Aggregating status for parent categories.\n  - Organizing UI navigation.\n\nConstraints:\n\n- `tree_id` for both parent and child must match.\n- No cross-tree edges.\n\n---\n\n### 1.2 Engine Families & Requirements\n\n**EngineFamily**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `name` – e.g., `"13B-REW"`.\n- `code` – unique stable identifier for programmatic use, e.g., `13B_REW`.\n- `rotor_count` – integer.\n- Optional attributes for future formula usage:\n  - `housing_count`\n  - `rotor_housing_pairs`\n  - etc., if the backend decides they’re useful.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Represents a type of rotary engine, characterized by core attributes used in formulas.\n- For EPIC 01, `rotor_count` is the main formula variable (e.g., `3 * rotor_count` for apex seals).\n\n---\n\n**CategoryRequirement**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `engine_family_id` – FK → `EngineFamily.id`.\n- `category_id` – FK → `Category.id`.\n- `formula` – string representing arithmetic expression, e.g., `"3 * rotor_count"`, `"2 * rotor_count"`.\n- `notes` – optional explanation.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Defines how many units of a category are required for a complete build for a specific engine family.\n- Formulas are always evaluated in a context that includes the engine family attributes (e.g., `rotor_count`).\n- The evaluated result must be a non-negative integer.\n\nFormula constraints:\n\n- Allowed tokens:\n  - Numeric literals: integers (`0`, `1`, `2`, `3`, …).\n  - EngineFamily attributes: at minimum `rotor_count`. Additional fields can be added in the future.\n  - Operators: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/` (integer division), parentheses.\n- No functions, no string concatenations, no conditionals in EPIC 01.\n- Example valid formulas:\n  - `3 * rotor_count`\n  - `2 * rotor_count + 4`\n  - `rotor_count * 2`\n- For MySQL implementation, backend may:\n  - Either parse/evaluate formulas in SQL via a constrained expression approach, or\n  - Precompute/evaluate with a helper/derived column.\n- Designer expectation: the tested seed for `13B-REW` + apex seals produces `required = 6` (3 apex seals per rotor × 2 rotors).\n\n---\n\n### 1.3 Parts, Categories, BOM/Kits\n\n**Part**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `sku` – vendor-agnostic internal SKU or code; unique.\n- `name` – human-readable.\n- `description` – optional detail.\n- `is_kit` – boolean:\n  - `false` → atomic part (no BOM expansion).\n  - `true` → kit part whose BOM is defined via `PartComponent`.\n- Optional:\n  - `uom` – unit of measure (e.g., `"piece"`, `"set"`), informational for now.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Master list of all parts, including both atomic components and kits.\n- Kits are logical groupings that expand into multiple `PartComponent` rows.\n\n---\n\n**PartCategory**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `part_id` – FK → `Part.id`.\n- `category_id` – FK → `Category.id`.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Associates parts (or kits) with one or more categories.\n- For completion, the **effective part units after BOM expansion** are mapped through these associations.\n- Design assumption:\n  - Atomic parts should typically be mapped to exactly one category.\n  - Kits may either be mapped:\n    - Directly to categories (if the entire kit conceptually belongs to a single category), and/or\n    - Indirectly via their component parts (if each component belongs to its own category).\n- For EPIC 01, completion logic should rely on component part category mappings where relevant, so BOM expansion is meaningful.\n\n---\n\n**PartComponent**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `kit_part_id` – FK → `Part.id` (where `Part.is_kit = true`).\n- `component_part_id` – FK → `Part.id` (the atomic or nested part).\n- `quantity` – numeric (integer).\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Defines BOM structure: a kit contains one or more component parts, each with its own quantity.\n- Expansion rule for completion:\n  - When a build selects a kit with quantity `Q`, and the BOM defines `quantity = q` for a component, the effective count of that component is `Q * q`.\n- Must support:\n  - Kits that expand into multiple categories via the categories assigned to the underlying component parts.\n  - Multiple kits contributing components to the same category.\n\nConstraints:\n\n- `kit_part_id` must reference a part where `is_kit = true`.\n- `component_part_id` can reference either atomic parts (`is_kit = false`) or nested kits, but for EPIC 01, BOM nesting is not required; a single level is sufficient.\n\n---\n\n### 1.4 Vendors & Offerings\n\n**Vendor**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `name` – vendor name.\n- `code` – optional short code.\n- `website` – optional.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Represents suppliers of parts.\n- Used to associate pricing/availability context with `Part` via `PartOffering`.\n\n---\n\n**PartOffering**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `vendor_id` – FK → `Vendor.id`.\n- `part_id` – FK → `Part.id`.\n- `price` – numeric (e.g., decimal).\n- `currency` – ISO currency code (e.g., `"USD"`).\n- `is_available` – boolean.\n- Optional:\n  - `sku_vendor` – vendor-specific SKU.\n  - `notes` – text for disclaimers, etc.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Connects a `Part` to a specific vendor.\n- EPIC 01 treats pricing/availability as stub fields; they’re not used directly by the completion query but must exist and be logically consistent with seed data.\n\n---\n\n### 1.5 Builds & Selections\n\n**Build**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `engine_family_id` – FK → `EngineFamily.id`.\n- `name` – e.g., `"13B-REW Street Build A"`.\n- `created_at` – timestamp.\n- Optional:\n  - `notes` – description of build intent.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Represents a specific engine build instance for a given engine family.\n- All requirements are derived from its `engine_family_id`.\n\n---\n\n**BuildSelection**\n\n- `id` – PK.\n- `build_id` – FK → `Build.id`.\n- `part_id` – FK → `Part.id`.\n- `quantity` – integer, number of units of this part (or kit) selected for the build.\n\nSemantics:\n\n- Captures user-selected parts for a build, including kits.\n- Completion logic must:\n  - Consider both direct selections of atomic parts, and\n  - Indirect contributions via kits, using BOM expansion.\n\nConstraints:\n\n- `quantity` must be non-negative; `0` can be allowed for editing workflows but is effectively ignored by completion logic.\n\n---\n\n## 2. Formula Model Specification\n\n### 2.1 Expression Scope\n\nFormulas in `CategoryRequirement.formula`:\n\n- Are evaluated **per engine family**.\n- Use only engine family attributes as variable symbols.\n- Must resolve to an integer number of required units.\n\nSupported variables (EPIC 01):\n\n- `rotor_count`\n\nSupported operators:\n\n- `+`, `-`, `*`, `/` (integer division).\n- Parentheses for grouping.\n\nDisallowed in EPIC 01:\n\n- Conditionals (`CASE`, `IF`), functions (`ROUND`, `CEIL`, etc.), string ops, comparison, logical operators.\n\n### 2.2 Evaluation Expectations\n\nThe backend is responsible for selecting a practical method that is:\n\n- Deterministic and testable via SQL.\n- Deterministic from seeded data (no randomness).\n\nPossible implementation patterns (backend is free to choose, but must align with tests/docs):\n\n1. **Direct Inline SQL Expressions**  \n   Store formulas as strings limited to a set of known templates, and transform/replace placeholders (e.g., replace `"rotor_count"` with actual numeric value in a view or derived query).\n\n2. **Precomputed Columns**  \n   Add a helper column `required_quantity` filled via migration/seed for the known combinations, and keep `formula` as documentation.\n\nDesigner expectations used in tests/docs:\n\n- For engine family `13B-REW` (`rotor_count = 2`) and category `"apex seals"` with formula `"3 * rotor_count"`, the completion query must calculate:\n\n  - `required_quantity = 6`.\n\nOther categories (example ideas for seeds, conceptual only):\n\n- `side seals` might be `formula = 6 * rotor_count` (or similar).\n- `coolant seals` might be `formula = 10 * rotor_count` (or any consistent demonstration).\n\nThe precise numeric choices are left to backend/seed, but must be used consistently across schema, seeds, and test expectations.\n\n---\n\n## 3. Completion Logic Narrative\n\n### 3.1 Overview\n\nGoal: For a given build:\n\n1. Determine required quantity per category.\n2. Determine supplied quantity per category based on selected parts and kits.\n3. Classify each category’s status (`complete`, `partial`, `missing`).\n4. Compute a progress metric (`progress` in [0,1]).\n5. Optionally compute an overall build status (e.g., worst-case or aggregate progress).\n\nThis logic will be expressed in SQL as a canonical query or view (e.g., `build_category_completion`) documented in `docs/DATA_MODEL.md`.\n\n### 3.2 Required Quantity per Category\n\nInputs:\n\n- `Build` → `engine_family_id`.\n- `EngineFamily` attributes (e.g., `rotor_count`).\n- `CategoryRequirement` rows for that engine family.\n\nAlgorithm (conceptual):\n\n1. **Identify engine family:**\n\n   - Given `build_id = B`, find `engine_family_id = EF`.\n\n2. **Fetch category requirements:**\n\n   - For all `CategoryRequirement` rows where `engine_family_id = EF`, collect `(category_id, formula)`.\n\n3. **Evaluate formula per category:**\n\n   - Substitute engine family attributes into `formula` and evaluate expression to compute `required_quantity` (integer).\n   - Any category with no requirement row is treated as:\n     - `required_quantity = 0` (no requirement) and usually excluded from completion output, or\n     - Shown with `required_quantity = 0` and `status = complete` by definition.\n   - EPIC 01 expectation: only categories with defined requirements need to appear in the completion query/view, but this should be clarified in docs.\n\nResult: a set of `(category_id, required_quantity)` for the target build.\n\n### 3.3 Supplied Quantity per Category\n\nInputs:\n\n- `BuildSelection` rows for the given `build_id`.\n- `Part` (`is_kit`).\n- `PartComponent` BOM for kits.\n- `PartCategory` associations for atomic parts (and possibly kits as needed).\n\nAlgorithm (conceptual):\n\n1. **Gather direct part selections:**\n\n   - For each `BuildSelection` row where `build_id = B`, get `(part_id, quantity_selected)`.\n\n2. **Classify parts as kits or atomic:**\n\n   - Join each `part_id` to `Part.is_kit`.\n\n3. **Compute effective counts:**\n\n   - For **atomic parts** (`is_kit = false`):\n     - Effective part count = `quantity_selected`.\n   - For **kits** (`is_kit = true`):\n     - Look up `PartComponent` rows where `kit_part_id = part_id`.\n     - For each component:\n       - `component_effective_count = quantity_selected * quantity_in_bom`.\n     - Kits themselves may or may not directly contribute to categories; for EPIC 01, the key contributions are via components.\n\n4. **Map parts/components to categories:**\n\n   - For each atomic part, join to `PartCategory` to get one or more `category_id`s.\n   - If a part is associated with multiple categories, its effective count contributes fully to each associated category (unless backend chooses to introduce weights, which EPIC 01 does NOT require).\n   - For kit components, use the component’s own `PartCategory` mapping.\n\n5. **Aggregate supplied quantities:**\n\n   - For each `category_id`, sum effective counts of all atomic parts and kit components mapped to that category.\n\nResult: a set of `(category_id, supplied_quantity)`.\n\n### 3.4 Per-Category Status & Progress\n\nInputs:\n\n- Required: `(category_id, required_quantity)`.\n- Supplied: `(category_id, supplied_quantity)`.\n\nAlgorithm (per category):\n\n- If `required_quantity > 0`:\n  - If `supplied_quantity >= required_quantity`:\n    - `status = \'complete\'`\n    - `progress = 1.0`\n  - Else if `supplied_quantity > 0 AND supplied_quantity < required_quantity`:\n    - `status = \'partial\'`\n    - `progress = supplied_quantity / required_quantity` (float, e.g., `0.5`).\n  - Else (`supplied_quantity = 0`):\n    - `status = \'missing\'`\n    - `progress = 0.0`\n- If `required_quantity = 0`:\n  - By default, either:\n    - Omit this category from the output, or\n    - Include it with:\n      - `supplied_quantity` as computed.\n      - `status = \'complete\'` (no requirement).\n      - `progress = 1.0`.\n  - For EPIC 01, tests should focus on categories with `required_quantity > 0`.\n\nAdditional fields (for view/query):\n\n- `category_name` (denormalized from `Category`).\n- `category_code`.\n- `engine_family_name`.\n- `build_id` / `build_name`.\n\n---\n\n### 3.5 Overall Build Status / Progress\n\nWhile not strictly required to be sophisticated, an overall metric is useful for the UI and tests.\n\nRecommended options (backend may choose one and document):\n\n1. **Worst-Category Status (strict):**\n\n   - If any required category is `missing` → overall `status = \'missing\'`.\n   - Else if any required category is `partial` → overall `status = \'partial\'`.\n   - Else (all required categories `complete`) → overall `status = \'complete\'`.\n\n2. **Average Progress (numeric):**\n\n   - `overall_progress = AVG(progress)` across all required categories (or weighted by `required_quantity`).\n\nFor EPIC 01:\n\n- At minimum, compute `overall_status` using the worst-category rule and an `overall_progress` value that is the average progress across required categories.\n- These may be computed in:\n  - The same view if convenient, or\n  - A separate summary query/view.\n\n---\n\n### 3.6 Example Scenarios with `13B-REW`\n\nAssume:\n\n- Engine family: `13B-REW`, `rotor_count = 2`.\n- Requirements (conceptual examples):\n\n  - `apex seals`: `formula = "3 * rotor_count"` → required = 6.\n  - `side seals`: some positive formula.\n  - `coolant seals`: some positive formula.\n\n#### 3.6.1 Fully Complete Category (apex seals)\n\n- Build selections include:\n  - Atomic apex seal parts or kits whose BOM expands to apex seal parts.\n- After BOM and aggregation:\n  - `supplied_quantity (apex seals) >= 6`.\n- Result:\n  - `status = \'complete\'`\n  - `progress = 1.0`.\n\n#### 3.6.2 Partially Complete Category\n\n- Suppose requirement: `coolant seals required = 8`.\n- BOM-expanded selections yield: `supplied_quantity (coolant seals) = 5`.\n- Result:\n  - `status = \'partial\'`\n  - `progress = 5/8 = 0.625`.\n\n#### 3.6.3 Missing Category\n\n- Suppose requirement: `side seals required = 12`.\n- Build selections contain no parts mapped to side seals → `supplied_quantity = 0`.\n- Result:\n  - `status = \'missing\'`\n  - `progress = 0.0`.\n\nSeed data must include builds and selections that demonstrate all three status cases.\n\n---\n\n## 4. Blazor UX Outline\n\nThe frontend will implement a simple Build Completion page based on this specification.\n\n### 4.1 Page Purpose and Route\n\n- Route: `/build-completion` (exact route name may deviate but should be stable).\n- Page name (in Nav): “Build Completion”.\n- Purpose:\n  - Display per-category completion status for a selected build.\n  - Provide a visual verification that the completion model works (complete/partial/missing).\n\n### 4.2 Data Model (UI-Level)\n\nA C# view model type (e.g., `BuildCategoryCompletionRow`) per row:\n\n- `string CategoryName`\n- `string CategoryCode`\n- `int RequiredQuantity`\n- `int SuppliedQuantity`\n- `string Status`  // `"complete" | "partial" | "missing"`\n- `double Progress`  // 0.0–1.0\n\nOptional fields for header/summary:\n\n- `int BuildId`\n- `string BuildName`\n- `string EngineFamilyName`\n- `double OverallProgress`  // 0.0–1.0\n- `string OverallStatus`  // `"complete" | "partial" | "missing"`\n\nFor EPIC 01, data may be mocked/in-memory, but property names should be chosen to match the output shape of the canonical SQL query/view.\n\n### 4.3 Layout & Content\n\nCore layout:\n\n1. **Page Header**\n   - Integrate this with the existing Blazor WebAssembly app (in `app/`) so the data model and completion logic can be exercised locally.\n\n## Target Users\n- Internal developers and data engineers defining engine build logic.\n- QA/testers validating build-completion behavior.\n- Future UI engineers who will surface build completion status in the Blazor app.\n\n## Key Functional Requirements\n\n### 1. Database Schema\nCreate initial MySQL schema and migrations to support build completion logic.\n\nDeliverable: `db/migrations/001_init.sql`\n\nMust define (at minimum) tables:\n\n- **Category**\n  - Represents conceptual groupings (e.g., apex seals, side seals, coolant seals, etc.).\n  - Supports multiple trees (e.g., "core").\n\n- **CategoryTree**\n  - Defines logical trees (e.g., “core”) for organizing categories.\n\n- **CategoryEdge**\n  - Supports hierarchical/category graph relationships within a tree.\n\n- **EngineFamily**\n  - Example: `13B-REW` with `rotor_count=2`.\n  - Must support formula-based requirements (e.g., requirements referencing `rotor_count`).\n\n- **CategoryRequirement**\n  - Links `EngineFamily` to `Category` with formula rules for required quantities.\n  - Must support formula like `3 * rotor_count` for apex seals.\n  - Formulas must be evaluable within SQL or via a well-defined approach (e.g., simple arithmetic expressions over known engine attributes).\n\n- **Part**\n  - Master list of parts (individual pieces and kits).\n  - Must distinguish between atomic parts and kits (BOM-based).\n\n- **PartCategory**\n  - Associates parts with one or more categories (for completion aggregation).\n\n- **PartComponent**\n  - Defines BOM relationships (kit → component parts and quantities).\n  - Must allow kits that expand into multiple underlying parts across categories.\n\n- **Vendor**\n  - Represents suppliers for parts.\n\n- **PartOffering**\n  - Vendor-specific offerings of parts, with pricing/availability fields (at least stubbed).\n\n- **Build**\n  - Represents a specific engine build instance for a given engine family.\n\n- **BuildSelection**\n  - User-selected parts (including kits) associated with a build.\n  - Must allow quantity per selected part.\n\n### 2. Seed Data\nDeliverable: `db/seeds/seed_minimal.sql`\n\nSeed a minimal but non-trivial dataset that demonstrates completion logic:\n\n- At least one **EngineFamily**: `13B-REW` with `rotor_count=2`.\n- At least one **CategoryTree**: `"core"`.\n- Categories including at least:\n  - apex seals\n  - side seals\n  - coolant seals\n  - additional related categories as needed.\n- **CategoryRequirement** entries:\n  - Formula-based quantity requirements using engine family attributes.\n  - Example: `apex_seals_required = 3 * rotor_count` for `13B-REW`.\n- At least 30 **Part** records across categories.\n  - Include both individual parts and kits.\n- At least 2 **kits** that expand via **PartComponent** (BOM) into multiple components.\n  - Kits must meaningfully affect completion counts when expanded.\n- At least one **Build** linked to `13B-REW` with **BuildSelection** rows that:\n  - Demonstrate fully complete, partially complete, and under-supplied scenarios per category.\n\n### 3. Completion Query\nDeliverables:\n- Implementation within schema/SQL as a view or representative query (documented in `docs/DATA_MODEL.md`).\n- Test coverage in `TEST.md` for correctness.\n\nRequirements:\n\n- Must compute, for a given build:\n  - Required count per category:\n    - Use engine-specific category requirements.\n    - Interpret formulas (e.g., `3 * rotor_count`) correctly.\n  - Supplied pieces per category:\n    - Expand kits into their component parts using `PartComponent`.\n    - Aggregate quantities across direct parts and kit components.\n  - Compare required vs supplied:\n    - Determine a per-category status:\n      - `complete` (supplied ≥ required)\n      - `partial` (0 < supplied < required)\n      - `missing` (supplied = 0 but required > 0)\n    - Compute progress metric per category (e.g., `supplied / required`, capped at 1.0).\n  - Provide an overall build status/progress summary (e.g., based on worst category or aggregate).\n\n- The completion query must be:\n  - Deterministic and repeatable from seed data.\n  - Usable in automated tests (no reliance on non-seeded rows).\n\n### 4. Integrate this with the existing Blazor WebAssembly app (in `app/`) so the data model and completion logic can be exercised locally.\n\n## Target Users\n- Internal developers and data engineers defining engine build logic.\n- QA/testers validating build-completion behavior.\n- Future UI engineers who will surface build completion status in the Blazor app.\n\n## Key Functional Requirements\n\n### 1. Database Schema\nCreate initial MySQL schema and migrations to support build completion logic.\n\nDeliverable: `db/migrations/001_init.sql`\n\nMust define (at minimum) tables:\n\n- **Category**\n  - Represents conceptual groupings (e.g., apex seals, side seals, coolant seals, etc.).\n  - Supports multiple trees (e.g., "core").\n\n- **CategoryTree**\n  - Defines logical trees (e.g., “core”) for organizing categories.\n\n- **CategoryEdge**\n  - Supports hierarchical/category graph relationships within a tree.\n\n- **EngineFamily**\n  - Example: `13B-REW` with `rotor_count=2`.\n  - Must support formula-based requirements (e.g., requirements referencing `rotor_count`).\n\n- **CategoryRequirement**\n  - Links `EngineFamily` to `Category` with formula rules for required quantities.\n  - Must support formula like `3 * rotor_count` for apex seals.\n  - Formulas must be evaluable within SQL or via a well-defined approach (e.g., simple arithmetic expressions over known engine attributes).\n\n- **Part**\n  - Master list of parts (individual pieces and kits).\n  - Must distinguish between atomic parts and kits (BOM-based).\n\n- **PartCategory**\n  - Associates parts with one or more categories (for completion aggregation).\n\n- **PartComponent**\n  - Defines BOM relationships (kit → component parts and quantities).\n  - Must allow kits that expand into multiple underlying parts across categories.\n\n- **Vendor**\n  - Represents suppliers for parts.\n\n- **PartOffering**\n  - Vendor-specific offerings of parts, with pricing/availability fields (at least stubbed).\n\n- **Build**\n  - Represents a specific engine build instance for a given engine family.\n\n- **BuildSelection**\n  - User-selected parts (including kits) associated with a build.\n  - Must allow quantity per selected part.\n\n### 2. Seed Data\nDeliverable: `db/seeds/seed_minimal.sql`\n\nSeed a minimal but non-trivial dataset that demonstrates completion logic:\n\n- At least one **EngineFamily**: `13B-REW` with `rotor_count=2`.\n- At least one **CategoryTree**: `"core"`.\n- Categories including at least:\n  - apex seals\n  - side seals\n  - coolant seals\n  - additional related categories as needed.\n- **CategoryRequirement** entries:\n  - Formula-based quantity requirements using engine family attributes.\n  - Example: `apex_seals_required = 3 * rotor_count` for `13B-REW`.\n- At least 30 **Part** records across categories.\n  - Include both individual parts and kits.\n- At least 2 **kits** that expand via **PartComponent** (BOM) into multiple components.\n  - Kits must meaningfully affect completion counts when expanded.\n- At least one **Build** linked to `13B-REW` with **BuildSelection** rows that:\n  - Demonstrate fully complete, partially complete, and under-supplied scenarios per category.\n\n### 3. Completion Query\nDeliverables:\n- Implementation within schema/SQL as a view or representative query (documented in `docs/DATA_MODEL.md`).\n- Test coverage in `TEST.md` for correctness.\n\nRequirements:\n\n- Must compute, for a given build:\n  - Required count per category:\n    - Use engine-specific category requirements.\n    - Interpret formulas (e.g., `3 * rotor_count`) correctly.\n  - Supplied pieces per category:\n    - Expand kits into their component parts using `PartComponent`.\n    - Aggregate quantities across direct parts and kit components.\n  - Compare required vs supplied:\n    - Determine a per-category status:\n      - `complete` (supplied ≥ required)\n      - `partial` (0 < supplied < required)\n      - `missing` (supplied = 0 but required > 0)\n    - Compute progress metric per category (e.g., `supplied / required`, capped at 1.0).\n  - Provide an overall build status/progress summary (e.g., based on worst category or aggregate).\n\n- The completion query must be:\n  - Deterministic and repeatable from seed data.\n  - Usable in automated tests (no reliance on non-seeded rows).\n\n### 4. Documentation\nDeliverables:\n- `docs/DATA_MODEL.md` updated.\n- `README.md` in project root.\n- `logs/CHANGELOG.md` updated.\n\nRequirements:\n\n- **docs/DATA_MODEL.md**\n  - Update to include all new/changed tables with column names, types, and primary/foreign keys.\n  - Document how:\n    - Category trees and edges work.\n    - Engine family and requirements are modeled.\n    - Kits and BOM expansion work via `PartComponent`.\n    - The completion query or view is structured conceptually.\n\n- **README.md** (project root)\n  - Explain:\n    - Project purpose for EPIC 01.\n    - How to set up MySQL (connection details or assumptions).\n    - How to apply migrations (`001_init.sql`) and seeds (`seed_minimal.sql`).\n    - How to run the Blazor WebAssembly app locally using:\n      - `cd app`\n      - `dotnet run`\n    - Any configuration necessary for the Blazor app to talk to the database or simulate/use completion logic.\n\n- **logs/CHANGELOG.md**\n  - Add a concise summary line for this run describing:\n    - Schema creation.\n    - Seed data addition.\n    - Completion query availability.\n\n### 5. Blazor WebAssembly Integration\nConstraints and requirements:\n\n- Work **only** inside existing `app/` folder for application code.\n  - Do **not** create new `frontend/` or `backend/` directories for UI or API.\n- Update existing or add new files under:\n  - `app/Program.cs`\n  - `app/Pages/*`\n  - `app/wwwroot/*`\n- Provide at least a minimal UI surface to:\n  - Show sample build completion status (even if using mock data or a thin integration).\n  - Optionally allow switching between builds from seeded data.\n- Confirm in documentation that app runs via:\n  - `cd app`\n  - `dotnet run`\n\nImplementation detail expectations:\n\n- Decide and document:\n  - Whether the Blazor app reads from a live MySQL database (likely via an API/backend) or uses precomputed SQL query results / mock data for the purpose of this epic.\n  - Any configuration values (connection strings, endpoints) and where they are stored.\n\n## Non-Functional Requirements & Constraints\n\n- **Technology**\n  - Database: MySQL-compatible SQL.\n  - UI: Existing Blazor WebAssembly project in `app/`.\n  - No new backend project folders outside `app/`, unless they logically belong under `app/` (e.g., `app/Server` in an existing hosted model).\n\n- **Performance**\n  - Completion query should be efficient enough for interactive use on a single build (reasonable limits given small dataset).\n\n- **Data Quality**\n  - Seed data must be internally consistent:\n    - Part-component quantities match expected kit expansions.\n    - Category requirements align with engine family attributes.\n    - No orphaned foreign keys.\n\n- **Maintainability**\n  - Schema and queries must be readable and commented where non-obvious (especially formula evaluation).\n  - Data model doc and tests must be kept in sync with schema.\n\n---\n\nAGENT_TASKS.md:\n# AGENT TASKS – EPIC 01: Data Foundation\n\n## Shared Project Context\n**Project Name:** EPIC_01_Data_Foundation\n\n**Global Deliverables**\n- `db/migrations/001_init.sql` – Initial MySQL schema and objects.\n- `db/seeds/seed_minimal.sql` – Minimal but rich seed dataset.\n- `docs/DATA_MODEL.md` – Updated with full schema and completion logic description.\n- `README.md` (project root) – Setup and run instructions (DB + Blazor app).\n- `logs/CHANGELOG.md` – Updated with a new summary line for this epic.\n- Blazor updates under `app/`:\n  - **Left rail**: category tree.\n    - **Center panel**: parts list for selected category.\n    - **Right rail**: summary (completion %, cost) and warnings.\n\n### Left Rail – CategoryTree\n\n- Displays **exactly 10 categories** (static seeded list is acceptable).\n- Categories represent logical groups of parts for the build.\n- Selecting a category updates the center panel parts list.\n- The currently selected category is visually distinguished.\n\n### Center Panel – PartsList\n\n- For the selected category, shows relevant parts:\n  - Product Summary\n\nBuild a minimal Compatibility feature set into the existing Blazor WebAssembly app (inside `app/`) that allows defining attributes on parts, evaluating compatibility rules, and surfacing warnings to the user via a dedicated panel.\n\n## 2. Target Users\n\n- Internal engineers / product owners configuring and validating part combinations.\n- Potential future end-users who assemble configurations (e.g., product configurator, BOM builder) and need to see compatibility warnings in real time.\n\n## 3. Core Goals\n\n1. **AttributeDef + PartAttribute**\n   - Support defining attribute types/metadata (AttributeDef).\n   - Support associating attributes with parts or part-like entities (PartAttribute).\n   - Ensure the UI can display and (if in scope) edit these attributes.\n\n2. **CompatRule Evaluator**\n   - Define a representation for compatibility rules (CompatRule).\n   - Implement an evaluation engine that:\n     - Accepts a set of parts and their attributes.\n     - Evaluates rules and emits compatibility results (pass/fail/warn).\n   - Ensure the evaluator is usable from Blazor components (e.g., services or shared logic layer in `app/`).\n\n3. **Warnings Panel**\n   - Add a UI panel that shows current compatibility warnings.\n   - The panel should update when the underlying configuration/selection changes.\n   - Warnings should be understandable: reference the rule or attribute causing the warning.\n\n## 4. Functional Requirements\n\n### 4.1 Attribute Definition and Assignment\n\n- Define a model for `AttributeDef` with, at minimum:\n  - Stable identifier (e.g., `Id` or `Key`).\n  - Display name.\n  - Data type (e.g., string, number, enum/choice), if needed by rules.\n  - Optional description or help text.\n- Define a model for `PartAttribute` with, at minimum:\n  - Reference to a part (or part ID).\n  - Reference to an `AttributeDef`.\n  - A value consistent with the attribute’s data type.\n- Provide a way (service, sample data, or simple input) to:\n  - Load or define a set of `AttributeDef` instances.\n  - Load or define `PartAttribute` instances for test/demo purposes.\n- Display attributes for at least one sample part in the UI.\n\n### 4.2 Compatibility Rules and Evaluation\n\n- Define a model for `CompatRule` with:\n  - Unique identifier.\n  - Human-readable name/description.\n  - A condition that can be evaluated against a set of parts and their attributes.\n  - A severity or result type (e.g., Warning, Error, Info).\n- Implement a `CompatRuleEvaluator` (class or service) that:\n  - Accepts a set of parts and their attributes as input.\n  - Evaluates all active `CompatRule` instances.\n  - Returns a structured list of results (e.g., rule ID, message, severity, affected part(s)).\n- Provide a way to trigger evaluation from the Blazor UI:\n  - Automatically on configuration changes, or\n  - Via an explicit button/action (at least one must exist in the MVP).\n\n### 4.3 Warnings Panel UI\n\n- Implement a warnings panel component/page (e.g., in `app/Pages/` or `app/Shared/`):\n  - Displays a list of current warnings and/or errors from the CompatRule evaluator.\n  - Each entry should include:\n    - User-friendly message.\n    - Severity (at least “Warning”; optionally “Error”/“Info”).\n    - Reference to the underlying rule or part where helpful.\n  - Should visually distinguish “no warnings” vs “warnings present”.\n- Integrate this panel into the existing app layout or a dedicated page:\n  - Accessible via navigation or embedded on a relevant page.\n  - Updates when the evaluated configuration changes.\n\n## 5. Non-Functional Requirements & Constraints\n\n- **Tech stack**:\n  - Blazor WebAssembly.\n  - Work **only** in the existing `app/` folder.\n  - Do **not** create separate `frontend/` or `backend` folders for the app UI.\n- **Code locations**:\n  - Blazor files such as:\n    - `app/Program.cs`\n    - `app/Pages/*`\n    - `app/Shared/*` (if used)\n    - `app/wwwroot/*` (for static content, CSS, or configuration files as needed)\n- **Local run instructions**:\n  - The project must be runnable via:\n    - `cd app`\n    - `dotnet run`\n  - `README.md` in the project root must clearly describe:\n    - Prerequisites (.NET SDK version).\n    - How to run the Blazor WASM app locally.\n    - Where to find/use the Compatibility features and warnings panel.\n- **Change tracking**:\n  - `logs/CHANGELOG.md` must be updated with a concise summary line for this run/iteration of EPIC 03.\n- **MVP scope**:\n  - Focus on minimum viable functionality that demonstrates:\n    - Attributes associated with parts.\n    - Rules evaluated against those attributes.\n    - Warnings surfaced in the UI.\n  - Robust persistence, complex data modeling, and advanced UX are out of scope for this EPIC unless trivial to add.\n\n## 6. Target Users\n\n- Internal engineers / product owners configuring and validating part combinations.\n- Potential future end-users who assemble configurations (e.g., product configurator, BOM builder) and need to see compatibility warnings in real time.\n\n## 3. Core Goals\n\n1. **AttributeDef + PartAttribute**\n   - Support defining attribute types/metadata (AttributeDef).\n   - Support associating attributes with parts or part-like entities (PartAttribute).\n   - Ensure the UI can display and (if in scope) edit these attributes.\n\n2. **CompatRule Evaluator**\n   - Define a representation for compatibility rules (CompatRule).\n   - Implement an evaluation engine that:\n     - Accepts a set of parts and their attributes.\n     - Evaluates rules and emits compatibility results (pass/fail/warn).\n   - Ensure the evaluator is usable from Blazor components (e.g., services or shared logic layer in `app/`).\n\n3. **Warnings Panel**\n   - Add a UI panel that shows current compatibility warnings.\n   - The panel should update when the underlying configuration/selection changes.\n   - Warnings should be understandable: reference the rule or attribute causing the warning.\n\n## 4. Functional Requirements\n\n### 4.1 Attribute Definition and Assignment\n\n- Define a model for `AttributeDef` with, at minimum:\n  - Stable identifier (e.g., `Id` or `Key`).\n  - Display name.\n  - Data type (e.g., string, number, enum/choice), if needed by rules.\n  - Optional description or help text.\n- Define a model for `PartAttribute` with, at minimum:\n  - Reference to a part (or part ID).\n  - Reference to an `AttributeDef`.\n  - A value consistent with the attribute’s data type.\n- Provide a way (service, sample data, or simple input) to:\n  - Load or define a set of `AttributeDef` instances.\n  - Load or define `PartAttribute` instances for test/demo purposes.\n- Display attributes for at least one sample part in the UI.\n\n### 4.2 Compatibility Rules and Evaluation\n\n- Define a model for `CompatRule` with:\n  - Unique identifier.\n  - Human-readable name/description.\n  - A condition that can be evaluated against a set of parts and their attributes.\n  - A severity or result type (e.g., Warning, Error, Info).\n- Implement a `CompatRuleEvaluator` (class or service) that:\n  - Accepts a set of parts and their attributes as input.\n  - Evaluates all active `CompatRule` instances.\n  - Returns a structured list of results (e.g., rule ID, message, severity, affected part(s)).\n- Provide a way to trigger evaluation from the Blazor UI:\n  - Automatically on configuration changes, or\n  - Via an explicit button/action (at least one must exist in the MVP).\n\n### 4.3 Warnings Panel UI\n\n- Implement a warnings panel component/page (e.g., in `app/Pages/` or `app/Shared/`):\n  - Displays a list of current warnings and/or errors from the CompatRule evaluator.\n  - Each entry should include:\n    - User-friendly message.\n    - Severity (at least “Warning”; optionally “Error”/“Info”).\n    - Reference to the underlying rule or part where helpful.\n  - Should visually distinguish “no warnings” vs “warnings present”.\n- Integrate this panel into the existing app layout or a dedicated page:\n  - Accessible via navigation or embedded on a relevant page.\n  - Updates when the evaluated configuration changes.\n\n## 5. README Content Inputs\n------------------------\n\nThese are suggested text blocks that can be adapted directly into the root `README.md`.\n\n### 1.1 Short Overview of Compatibility MVP\n\n**Section title idea:** `## Compatibility MVP (EPIC 03)`\n\n**Body text (editable draft):**\n\nThe Compatibility MVP adds a simple way to define attributes on parts, run compatibility rules against a configuration, and surface any resulting warnings in the UI.\n\nEach part can have one or more attributes (for example, “Voltage”, “Color”, or “Form Factor”). Compatibility rules check combinations of parts and their attributes and return warnings or errors when something looks incorrect or risky. A dedicated warnings panel shows these results so that engineers and product owners can quickly see if a configuration has known compatibility issues.\n\n### 1.2 User-Friendly Explanation of “Attributes” and “Compatibility Warnings”\n\n**Subsection: “What are attributes?”**\n\nAttributes describe characteristics of a part, such as its size, rating, or category. In this app:\n\n- An **Attribute Definition** defines the metadata for an attribute (e.g., a key like `voltage`, display name “Voltage”, data type “number”, and optional description).\n- A **Part Attribute** connects a specific part to one of these definitions and provides a concrete value (e.g., Part A has Voltage = 12).\n\nAttributes are used by the compatibility rules to determine whether selected parts work well together.\n\n**Subsection: “What are compatibility warnings?”**\n\nCompatibility warnings are messages generated when the system detects that a configuration might be invalid or suboptimal based on the defined rules. For example, a rule might warn if two parts have mismatched voltage ratings or incompatible form factors.\n\nEach compatibility result has:\n\n- A **message** that explains the issue in plain language.\n- A **severity** that indicates how serious it is (e.g., Warning, Error, Info).\n- Optionally, a reference to the affected part(s) or rule.\n\nUsers should review warnings to decide whether to adjust the configuration or accept known limitations.\n\n### 1.3 Instructions: Where to See the Warnings Panel and How to Interpret It\n\n**Subsection: “Where to find the compatibility features”**\n\nSuggested README wording:\n\n1. Start the app:\n\n   - From the project root: `cd app`\n   - Then: `dotnet run`\n   - Open the provided URL in your browser.\n\n2. Navigate to the **Compatibility** page:\n   - Use the left-hand navigation menu (NavMenu).\n   - Click on **Compatibility** (or the configured route name).\n   - This page shows:\n     - A sample part and its attributes.\n     - A compatibility warnings panel.\n\n3. View the **Warnings Panel**:\n   - On the Compatibility page, the warnings panel appears on the right side (or below, on smaller screens).\n   - It lists any current compatibility warnings or errors for the sample configuration.\n   - You can trigger re-evaluation (if not automatic) by using the **Recalculate** or **Evaluate Compatibility** button on the page.\n\n**Subsection: “How to read the warnings panel”**\n\nSuggested text:\n\n- If there are **no compatibility issues**, the panel shows a clear empty state message such as:\n  - “No compatibility warnings. Your current configuration passes all rules.”\n- If there **are issues**, the panel shows a list where each item includes:\n  - A short, readable **message** describing the issue (e.g., “Power supply voltage (24V) does not match motor voltage (12V).”).\n  - A **severity label** such as “Warning”, “Error”, or “Info”.\n  - Optional references to affected parts or rules (e.g., “Rule: VoltageMatchRule”, “Parts: PSU-24V, Motor-12V”).\n\nUsers can scan this list to understand whether a configuration is acceptable, needs review, or should be corrected.\n\n---\n\n2. UI Layout & Styling Guidance\n-------------------------------\n\nThis section defines how the main Compatibility page and Warnings Panel should look and behave, using minimal, standard Blazor + CSS approaches.\n\n### 2.1 Overall Page Layout: “Compatibility” Page\n\n**Goals:**\n\n- Show at least one sample part and its attributes clearly.\n- Surface compatibility results in a dedicated, easy-to-scan area.\n- Keep structure simple and responsive.\n\n**Recommended layout:**\n\n- Page: `Pages/Compatibility.razor` (or similar).\n- Basic two-column layout on desktop:\n  - **Left column:** Part and attribute details + evaluation controls.\n  - **Right column:** Warnings panel.\n- On smaller screens, stack vertically:\n  - Part + attributes at the top.\n  - Warnings panel below.\n\n**Structure suggestion (semantic):**\n\n- Page title: “Compatibility” or “Compatibility Checker”.\n- Subsections:\n  1. “Selected Part(s) and Attributes”\n  2. “Compatibility Evaluation”\n     - Evaluate button and/or auto-update explanation.\n  3. “Compatibility Warnings” (the panel, can be implemented as a shared component).\n\n### 2.2 Attributes Display Section\n\n**Use case:**\n\nDisplay attributes for at least one sample part in the UI.\n\n**Recommended visual pattern:**\n\n- A simple, accessible table or definition list.\n- MVP-friendly: no dynamic editing required, but layout should leave room for future edit controls if desired.\n\n**Option A: Table-based layout (recommended)**\n\n- Columns:\n  - Attribute Name (from AttributeDef.DisplayName).\n  - Value (from PartAttribute.Value, formatted based on data type when possible).\n  - Description / Help (optional, from AttributeDef.Description).\n\nExample headers:\n\n- “Attribute”\n- “Value”\n- “Details”\n\n**Formatting guidance:**\n\n- Use clear, bold header row.\n- Left-align text for readability.\n- If a value is missing or not applicable, show “—” or “Not set” instead of leaving the cell blank.\n\n**Inline content guidance:**\n\n- Above the table: a short description such as:\n  - “Below are the attributes for the selected part. Compatibility rules use these values to detect potential issues.”\n- For multiple parts (if supported in demo):\n  - Use a simple list of part names above the attribute table, or separate tables per part with subheadings like “Part: Motor-12V”.\n\n### 2.3 Warnings Panel Component/Page\n\n**Component name suggestion:**\n\n- `Shared/WarningsPanel.razor` (to allow reuse) or a dedicated section in `Compatibility.razor` if simpler.\n\n**Panel framing:**\n\n- Title: “Compatibility Warnings”\n- Encapsulate the panel visually with:\n  - Product Summary\n\nBuild a minimal Compatibility feature set into the existing Blazor WebAssembly app (inside `app/`) that allows defining attributes on parts, evaluating compatibility rules, and surfacing warnings to the user via a dedicated panel.\n\n## 2. Target Users\n\n- Internal engineers / product owners configuring and validating part combinations.\n- Potential future end-users who assemble configurations (e.g., product configurator, BOM builder) and need to see compatibility warnings in real time.\n\n## 3. Core Goals\n\n1. **AttributeDef + PartAttribute**\n   - Support defining attribute types/metadata (AttributeDef).\n   - Support associating attributes with parts or part-like entities (PartAttribute).\n   - Ensure the UI can display and (if in scope) edit these attributes.\n\n2. **CompatRule Evaluator**\n   - Define a representation for compatibility rules (CompatRule).\n   - Implement an evaluation engine that:\n     - Accepts a set of parts and their attributes.\n     - Evaluates rules and emits compatibility results (pass/fail/warn).\n   - Ensure the evaluator is usable from Blazor components (e.g., services or shared logic layer in `app/`).\n\n3. **Warnings Panel**\n   - Add a UI panel that shows current compatibility warnings.\n   - The panel should update when the underlying configuration/selection changes.\n   - Warnings should be understandable: reference the rule or attribute causing the warning.\n\n## 4. Functional Requirements\n\n### 4.1 Attribute Definition and Assignment\n\n- Define a model for `AttributeDef` with, at minimum:\n  - Stable identifier (e.g., `Id` or `Key`).\n  - Display name.\n  - Data type (e.g., string, number, enum/choice), if needed by rules.\n  - Optional description or help text.\n- Define a model for `PartAttribute` with, at minimum:\n  - Reference to a part (or part ID).\n  - Reference to an `AttributeDef`.\n  - A value consistent with the attribute’s data type.\n- Provide a way (service, sample data, or simple input) to:\n  - Load or define a set of `AttributeDef` instances.\n  - Load or define `PartAttribute` instances for test/demo purposes.\n- Display attributes for at least one sample part in the UI.\n\n### 4.2 Compatibility Rules and Evaluation\n\n- Define a model for `CompatRule` with:\n  - Unique identifier.\n  - Human-readable name/description.\n  - A condition that can be evaluated against a set of parts and their attributes.\n  - A severity or result type (e.g., Warning, Error, Info).\n- Implement a `CompatRuleEvaluator` (class or service) that:\n  - Accepts a set of parts and their attributes as input.\n  - Evaluates all active `CompatRule` instances.\n  - Returns a structured list of results (e.g., rule ID, message, severity, affected part(s)).\n- Provide a way to trigger evaluation from the Blazor UI:\n  - Automatically on configuration changes, or\n  - Via an explicit button/action (at least one must exist in the MVP).\n\n### 4.3 Warnings Panel UI\n\n- Implement a warnings panel component/page (e.g., in `app/Pages/` or `app/Shared/`):\n  - Displays a list of current warnings and/or errors from the CompatRule evaluator.\n  - Each entry should include:\n    - User-friendly message.\n    - Severity (at least “Warning”; optionally “Error”/“Info”).\n    - Reference to the underlying rule or part where helpful.\n  - Should visually distinguish “no warnings” vs “warnings present”.\n- Integrate this panel into the existing app layout or a dedicated page:\n  - Accessible via navigation or embedded on a relevant page.\n  - Updates when the evaluated configuration changes.\n\n## 5. Non-Functional Requirements & Constraints\n\n- **Tech stack**:\n  - Blazor WebAssembly.\n  - Work **only** in the existing `app/` folder.\n  - Do **not** create separate `frontend/` or `backend` folders for the app UI.\n- **Code locations**:\n  - Blazor files such as:\n    - `app/Program.cs`\n    - `app/Pages/*`\n    - `app/Shared/*` (if used)\n    - `app/wwwroot/*` (for static content, CSS, or configuration files as needed)\n- **Local run instructions**:\n  - The project must be runnable via:\n    - `cd app`\n    - `dotnet run`\n  - `README.md` in the project root must clearly describe:\n    - Prerequisites (.NET SDK version).\n    - How to run the Blazor WASM app locally.\n    - Where to find/use the Compatibility features and warnings panel.\n- **Change tracking**:\n  - `logs/CHANGELOG.md` must be updated with a concise summary line for this run/iteration of EPIC 03.\n- **MVP scope**:\n  - Focus on minimum viable functionality that demonstrates:\n    - Attributes associated with parts.\n    - Rules evaluated against those attributes.\n    - Warnings surfaced in the UI.\n  - Robust persistence, complex data modeling, and advanced UX are out of scope for this EPIC unless trivial to add.\n\n## 6. Out-of-Scope (for this EPIC)\n\n- Full CRUD management of parts, attributes, and rules via production-ready UI.\n- Authentication/authorization.\n- Integration with external services or databases beyond whatever is already present.\n- Extensive styling or design system overhaul.\n- Multi-language localization.\n\n---\n\nAGENT_TASKS.md:\n# EPIC 03: Compatibility MVP – AGENT TASKS\n\n## Common Project Context\n\n- **Project Name:** Compatibility MVP (EPIC 03)\n- **Tech:** Blazor WebAssembly app in `app/`.\n- **Key Constraints:**\n  - Work **only** inside `app/` for app code.\n  - Do **not** create `frontend/` or `backend/` folders for UI.\n  - Use existing Blazor structure (`Program.cs`, `Pages/`, `Shared/`, `wwwroot/`).\n  - Root `README.md` must describe setup and run.\n  - `logs/CHANGELOG.md` must have a new summary line for this run.\n\n- **Required Shared Deliverables:**\n  - `README.md` (project root): Setup, run instructions, feature overview, and navigation to compatibility features.\n  - `logs/CHANGELOG.md`: New summary line describing EPIC 03 Compatibility MVP changes.\n  - Blazor implementation files inside `app/` to support:\n    - AttributeDef + PartAttribute.\n    - CompatRule evaluator.\n    - Warnings panel.\n\n---\n\n## 1. Designer\n\n### Project Name\nCompatibility MVP – UX & Content\n\n### Required Deliverables\n\n1. **README Content Inputs**\n   - Provide user-friendly text for:\n     - Short overview of Compatibility MVP.\n     - Explanation of what “attributes” and “compatibility warnings” mean in user terms.\n     - Instructions on where in the UI to see the warnings panel and how to interpret it.\n\n2. **UI Layout & Styling Guidance**\n   - Lightweight design notes for:\n     - Attributes display section (e.g., a table or list).\n     - Warnings panel component/page:\n       - Title, list formatting, empty state (“No compatibility warnings”).\n       - Severity differentiation (e.g., color, label, icon suggestions).\n\n3. **Acceptance Criteria Checklists (for testers)**\n   - Validate that:\n     - Attribute list is readable and clearly labeled.\n     - Warnings panel is distinguishable and easy to scan.\n     - Empty vs non-empty states are obvious.\n\n### Key Technical Notes and Constraints\n\n- No need to write C# code; provide design guidance that can be applied in `.razor` components.\n- Assume standard Blazor styling options:\n  - CSS in `app/wwwroot/css/*` or `app/wwwroot/` as available.\n- Work with minimal styling, prioritizing clarity over aesthetics for MVP.\n\n---\n\n## 2. Frontend\n\n### Project Name\nCompatibility MVP – Blazor UI\n\n### Required Deliverables\n\n1. **Blazor Pages/Components**\n   - New or updated `.razor` files inside `app/`:\n     - An attributes view page (e.g., `app/Pages/Compatibility.razor` or similar) that:\n       - Shows at least one part and its attributes using AttributeDef + PartAttribute models.\n     - A warnings panel component (e.g., `app/Shared/WarningsPanel.razor` or `app/Pages/Warnings.razor`) that:\n       - Lists compatibility warnings with severity markers.\n       - Handles empty state gracefully.\n\n2. **Integration with Data and Evaluator**\n   - Wire up the UI to:\n     - Retrieve or receive part data and attributes.\n     - Call the CompatRule evaluator (service/class) to get warning results.\n   - Ensure UI refreshes when configuration changes or when a “Recalculate” action is taken.\n\n3. **Navigation & Entry Points**\n   - Add navigation link(s) or clearly accessible route(s) to:\n     - The compatibility/attributes page.\n     - The warnings panel (if separate).\n   - Optionally update `app/Shared/NavMenu.razor` or equivalent.\n\n### Key Technical Notes and Constraints\n\n- Work only within `app/` (e.g., `app/Pages/*.razor`, `app/Shared/*.razor`, `app/wwwroot/*`).\n- Ensure compatibility with current Blazor WASM project setup (no breaking changes to `Program.cs` startup unless required).\n- Support running via:\n  - `cd app`\n  - `dotnet run`\n- Keep UI logic straightforward; MVP can rely on:\n  - In-memory data.\n  - Simple dependency injection for services (registered in `Program.cs`).\n\n---\n\n## 3. Backend\n\n### Project Name\nCompatibility MVP – Models & Services\n\n### Required Deliverables\n\n1. **Domain Models (C#)**\n   - Inside `app/` (e.g., `app/Models/` or equivalent existing folders):\n     - `AttributeDef`:\n       - Properties for Id/Key, DisplayName, optional DataType, optional Description.\n     - `PartAttribute`:\n       - Properties for PartId, AttributeDefId/Key, Value.\n     - `CompatRule`:\n       - Id, Name/Description, Severity, and a way to represent evaluation logic (delegate, expression, or pattern used by evaluator).\n     - `CompatEvaluationResult` (or similar):\n       - RuleId, Severity, Message, affected parts/attributes if needed.\n\n2. **Services**\n   - A data provider/service (e.g., `AttributeService`, `PartService`) that:\n     - Returns in-memory sample AttributeDefs, Parts, and PartAttributes for demo/testing.\n   - `CompatRuleEvaluator` service or class:\n     - Accepts part + attribute data and a set of CompatRules.\n     - Evaluates rules and returns a list of `CompatEvaluationResult`.\n\n3. **Configuration & DI**\n   - Register services in `app/Program.cs` (or equivalent) so they can be injected into Blazor components.\n   - Ensure there are no runtime DI errors.\n\n4. **Documentation & Change Log**\n   - Update **root** `README.md`:\n     - Confirm that instructions for `cd app && dotnet run` are present and correct.\n     - Add a section briefly explaining the new Compatibility MVP features and where they live in the UI.\n   - Append to `logs/CHANGELOG.md`:\n     - A one-line (or short) entry summarizing:\n       - EPIC 03 / Compatibility MVP.\n       - High-level items: attributes, rules, warnings panel.\n\n### Key Technical Notes and Constraints\n\n- Operate only within `app/` for code changes; do not split into `frontend/` or `backend/` folders.\n- Favor simple, maintainable implementations over complex frameworks for rules.\n- Testing:\n  - If a test project exists already, add tests there.\n  - Otherwise, ensure logic is easily testable and verifiable via UI and manual runs.\n- Ensure that calling `dotnet run` from `app/` compiles and runs without errors.\n\n---\n\n## 4. Tester\n\n### Project Name\nCompatibility MVP – Verification\n\n### Required Deliverables\n\n1. **Manual Test Scenarios**\n   - Document and execute scenarios that cover:\n     - Viewing a part and its attributes.\n     - Triggering compatibility evaluation.\n     - Seeing warnings appear when rules are violated.\n     - Confirming “no warnings” state when rules pass.\n\n2. **Verification of Documentation**\n   - Verify root `README.md`:\n     - Prerequisites are correct for the environment.\n     - Running instructions (`cd app`, `dotnet run`) launch the app as described.\n     - Navigation instructions to compatibility and warnings features are accurate.\n   - Verify `logs/CHANGELOG.md`:\n     - New entry is appended correctly.\n     - Content matches implemented features.\n\n3. **Bug/Issue Reporting**\n   - Log any issues where:\n     - UI does not update warnings as expected.\n     - Evaluator results do not match the known configuration.\n     - README or CHANGELOG information is inaccurate or misleading.\n\n### Key Technical Notes and Constraints\n\n- Primary interaction is via the running Blazor app in a browser.\n- If automated tests exist, run them and capture pass/fail status.\n- Validate behavior on at least one mainstream browser supported by the environment (e.g., Chromium-based).\n\nTEST.md:\n# EPIC 03: Compatibility MVP – TEST PLAN\n\n## 1.
