UX Goals & Principles\n\n- **Accuracy over flashiness**: Internal users prioritize correct, complete data over aesthetics.\n- **Low cognitive load**: Group related fields; keep forms linear and predictable.\n- **Visibility of normalization**: Always make it clear what changed between raw input and normalized output.\n- **Consistency with existing app**: Use existing layout, typography, and navigation patterns (e.g., shared layout components, standard Blazor form patterns).\n\n---\n\n## 2. Navigation & Information Architecture\n\n### 2.1. Top-Level Navigation Integration\n\nGiven this is an internal Blazor WASM SPA, assume a shared layout with a global navigation element (navbar or sidebar).\n\n**Add one primary entry point:**\n\n- **Nav item label**: “Vendor Offers”\n  - If there is a horizontal navbar:\n    - Add `Vendor Offers` as a top-level link.\n    - Default route for this nav link: `OffersList` (normalized offers list).\n  - If there is a sidebar:\n    - Add a section/heading “Vendor Management” (if similar sections exist) and under it:\n      - `Offers` (list)\n      - `New Offer` (manual entry form)\n    - If no sections are used, simply add both entries:\n      - `Vendor Offers`\n      - `New Offer`\n\n**Routing (conceptual):**\n\n- `/offers` → Normalized offers list (OffersList.razor).\n- `/offers/new` → Manual entry (ManualIngestion.razor) for creating a new offer.\n- `/offers/{id}` → Offer detail (OffersDetail.razor) to review raw vs normalized data.\n- `/offers/edit/{id}` → ManualIngestion.razor in “edit” mode (optional but recommended in design).\n\n### 2.2. Page Structure Overview\n\n1. **ManualIngestion.razor** – Manual entry form\n   - Purpose: Input/edit raw vendor offer data and submit for normalization + storage.\n   - Primary actions: Save & Normalize, Save as Draft (optional), Cancel.\n\n2. **OffersList.razor** – Normalized offers listing\n   - Purpose: Display normalized offers; allow quick review and navigation to details.\n   - Primary actions: Filter, View, Edit, Create new offer.\n\n3. **OffersDetail.razor** – Raw vs Normalized detail\n   - Purpose: Compare original entered data and normalized internal model.\n   - Primary actions: Edit, Back to list.\n\n---\n\n## 3. UX Flow: Manual Entry & Review\n\n### 3.1. End-to-End Flow (Happy Path)\n\n1. **User navigates to ingestion features**\n   - From main navigation: clicks `Vendor Offers` → arrives at OffersList.\n   - From OffersList: clicks `New Offer` → navigates to ManualIngestion.\n\n2. **User manually enters offer**\n   - Fills out fields in ManualIngestion form.\n   - Sees validation errors inline if fields are missing or invalid.\n   - Clicks `Save & Normalize`.\n\n3. **System behavior on submit**\n   - Client-side validation (Blazor DataAnnotations).\n   - If valid:\n     - Raw offer is passed to normalization service.\n     - Normalized offer is generated and stored by state service.\n     - User receives success feedback:\n       - Brief inline success message at top of form, and\n       - Auto-redirect to:\n         - Either OffersDetail for that offer (preferred to show transformation),\n         - Or OffersList with the new row highlighted.\n\n4. **User reviews the normalized offer**\n   - On OffersDetail:\n     - Sees **Raw Input** panel vs **Normalized Output** panel.\n   - Confirms that the normalization rules look correct.\n   - Optionally clicks `Edit` to adjust inconsistencies, which returns user to ManualIngestion with fields pre-populated.\n\n5. **User navigates back to list**\n   - From detail page, clicks `Back to list` to see normalized offers table.\n   - Can use filters to find offers later.\n\n### 3.2. Alternative Flows\n\n- **Incomplete entry / draft**\n  - If the app supports drafts:\n    - User can click `Save as Draft`.\n    - Status normalized as `Draft`.\n    - Draft items appear in OffersList with a “Draft” status badge.\n- **Validation failure**\n  - User clicks `Save & Normalize` with missing/invalid fields.\n  - Form remains on screen; fields with errors show:\n    - Red border / error icon (depending on existing design system).\n    - Inline error text under each invalid field.\n  - A summary message (e.g., “Please fix the errors below.”) at top of the form.\n\n---\n\n## 4. Screen Design – Manual Entry Form (ManualIngestion.razor)\n\n### 4.1. Page Layout\n\n- **Header**\n  - Title: `New Vendor Offer` or `Edit Vendor Offer` (depending on mode).\n  - Breadcrumb (if app uses them): `Home / Vendor Offers / New` or `Home / Vendor Offers / Edit`.\n\n- **Content Body**\n  - Centered responsive container with a max width (e.g., similar width as other forms).\n  - Group fields into logical sections with subheadings.\n\nSuggested sections:\n\n1. **Vendor Information**\n   - Vendor Name (required, text)\n   - Vendor Type (dropdown)\n     - Example enum options (to align with normalization): `Supplier`, `Partner`, `Distributor`, `Other`.\n   - Optional: Vendor Reference ID or External ID (text).\n\n2. **Offer Basics**\n   - Offer Name / Product or Service (required, text)\n   - Description (multi-line text area)\n   - Category (optional dropdown, if current app has something similar; otherwise free text).\n\n3. **Pricing & Currency**\n   - Currency (dropdown – e.g., `USD`, `EUR`, `GBP`, `Other`).\n   - Price / Amount (required, numeric with 2 decimal places).\n   - Optional: Unit (e.g., per user, per month – text or dropdown).\n\n4. **Dates & Status**\n   - Start Date (required, date picker)\n   - End Date (optional, date picker)\n   - Status (dropdown)\n     - Options mapped to normalized enum: `Draft`, `Proposed`, `Active`, `Expired`, `Cancelled`.\n   - Basic business rules:\n     - Start Date must be <= End Date (if End Date supplied).\n     - If End Date is in the past relative to current date, normalized status may be coerced to `Expired` (but this is handled by service; the UI just informs the user of the rule).\n\n5. **Meta / Source**\n   - Source (optional text; e.g., “Email”, “Call”, “Portal upload”).\n   - Internal Notes (optional multi-line text; for internal-only comments).\n\n### 4.2. Form Behaviors & Validation\n\nUse Blazor’s `EditForm`, `DataAnnotationsValidator`, and `ValidationMessage` components (following existing patterns).\n\n**Required fields (minimum):**\n\n- Vendor Name\n- Offer Name / Product or Service\n- Price / Amount\n- Currency\n- Start Date\n- Status\n\n**Validation specifics:**\n\n- **Text fields**: Non-empty for required fields; auto-trim whitespace on blur or on submit.\n- **Numeric field (Price)**:\n  - Positive decimal.\n  - Simple rule: `> 0`.\n- **Dates**:\n  - Valid date formats as per Blazor date input.\n  - Client-side check that Start Date ≤ End Date when End is filled.\n- **Status**:\n  - Must be a known enum value (from dropdown; no free-text).\n\n**Error representation:**\n\n- Each invalid field:\n  - Highlight with error color border.\n  - Show `ValidationMessage` below the field.\n- Top-of-form message:\n  - For example, a dismissible alert: “There are problems with your submission. Please fix the highlighted fields.”\n\n### 4.3. Actions & Buttons\n\nAt the bottom of the form (aligned right or consistent with existing form pattern):\n\n- **Primary button**: `Save & Normalize`\n  - On click:\n    - Validate form.\n    - On success, call normalization + state services.\n    - Navigate to OffersDetail for newly created/updated offer.\n\n- **Secondary button**: `Save as Draft` (optional)\n  - Sets raw model status to `Draft`.\n  - Normalization still occurs, but normalized status becomes `Draft`.\n  - Redirect behavior same as primary or simply stays with success message.\n\n- **Tertiary button/link**: `Cancel`\n  - Navigate back to OffersList without saving (or confirm if there are unsaved changes; optional).\n\n**Post-submit feedback:**\n\n- If redirecting to OffersDetail:\n  - A success alert at top of OffersDetail: “Offer saved and normalized.”\n- If staying on form:\n  - Success banner: “Offer saved and normalized. View it in the offers list.” with link to `/offers`.\n\n---\n\n## 5. Screen Design – Normalized Offers List (OffersList.razor)\n\n### 5.1. Page Layout\n\n- **Header**\n  - Title: `Vendor Offers`\n  - Optional subtitle: “Normalized view of all manually entered vendor offers.”\n\n- **Action bar (top-right or top-left)**\n  - `New Offer` button → navigates to `/offers/new`.\n  - Optional: Bulk actions (out of scope for this epic; not designed).\n\n- **Filters (top of list)**\n  - Simple filter row above table:\n    - Text search: “Search by vendor or product” (free text input).\n    - Status filter: dropdown with status list (`All`, `Draft`, `Proposed`, `Active`, `Expired`, `Cancelled`).\n    - Optional: Date range filter (Start Date, End Date) if needed.\n\n- **Table of normalized offers**\n  - Columns (suggested):\n    1. Vendor\n    2. Offer / Product\n    3. Price (Amount + Currency)\n    4. Date Range (Start – End)\n    5. Status (badge)\n    6. Updated On (or Created On)\n    7. Actions\n\n### 5.2. Normalized Data Presentation\n\n- **Vendor and Offer names**:\n  - Display in title case after normalization (e.g., “ACME CORP” → “Acme Corp”).\n- **Price**:\n  - Format as: `USD 1,234.50` or `$1,234.50` depending on existing pattern but with normalized currency code in the model.\n- **Dates**:\n  - Consistent short format (e.g., `2026-01-26` or `Jan 26, 2026` following app conventions).\n- **Status badge**:\n  - Use colored labels consistent with existing styles:\n    - `Draft` – gray\n    - `Proposed` – blue\n    - `Active` – green\n    - `Expired` – red\n    - `Cancelled` – dark red or outlined red\n\n### 5.3. Table Interactions\n\n- **Row-level actions (Actions column)**:\n  - `View` – navigates to `/offers/{id}` (OffersDetail).\n  - `Edit` – navigates to `/offers/edit/{id}` (ManualIngestion in edit mode).\n\n- **Row click behavior**:\n  - Optionally, clicking the row (excluding buttons) also navigates to `View`.\n\n- **Sorting (optional but recommended)**:\n  - Clicking on header cells for Vendor, Price, Start Date, or Status toggles sort.\n  - Visual indicator: sort arrow icon (ascending/descending).\n\n- **Empty state**:\n  - When no offers exist:\n    - Show an illustration or simple text: “No offers have been entered yet.”\n    - Provide a `New Offer` primary button in the empty state area.\n\n---\n\n## 6. Screen Design – Offer Detail & Normalization Review (OffersDetail.razor)\n\n### 6.1. Page Layout\n\n- **Header**\n  - Title: `Offer Details – [Vendor Name]`\n  - Optional subtitle: the Offer Name.\n\n- **Top actions**\n  - `Edit` button → `/offers/edit/{id}`.\n  - `Back to list` link/button → `/offers`.\n\n- **Content layout**\n  - Two-column layout on desktop, stacked on mobile:\n    - Left column: **Raw Input**\n    - Right column: **Normalized Output**\n\n### 6.2. Raw vs Normalized Panels\n\n**Raw Input panel:**\n\n- Section heading: “Raw Input”\n- Display fields as captured:\n  - Vendor Name\n  - Vendor Type\n  - Offer Name / Product\n  - Description\n  - Currency (raw – even if lowercased or extra spaces)\n  - Price (raw textual entry if different from parsed)\n  - Dates (as entered)\n  - Status (raw text)\n  - Source\n  - Notes\n- Layout: label + value pairs, stacked.\n\n**Normalized Output panel:**\n\n- Section heading: “Normalized Offer”\n- Display normalized model fields:\n  - VendorName (trimmed, standardized case)\n  - VendorType (enum label)\n  - ProductOrServiceName\n  - Description (trimmed)\n  - CurrencyCode (e.g., `USD`, `EUR`)\n  - Amount (formatted numeric)\n  - StartDate / EndDate (consistent date format; “Open-ended” if EndDate missing)\n  - Status (standardized enum; color badge same as list)\n  - Derived flags (if used; e.g., `IsCurrentlyActive` – optional for display).\n- If any normalization “fixes” were applied (e.g., status coerced from `Active` to `Expired` because the end date is past), consider:\n  - A small note line next to the field: e.g., “Normalized from value: Active” or a subtle info icon with tooltip (“Based on end date, status is normalized to Expired.”).\n  - This is optional but beneficial for transparency.\n\n### 6.3. Product Overview\n\nThis epic adds basic monetization to the existing Blazor WebAssembly app by introducing affiliate URLs and click attribution. Users interacting with monetizable links in the app should transparently trigger affiliate tracking while preserving a smooth, reliable UI experience.\n\nThe work must be implemented inside the existing `app/` Blazor WebAssembly project only.\n\n## 2. Goals\n\n1. **Affiliate URLs**\n   - Support rendering and use of affiliate URLs within relevant Blazor pages.\n   - Keep affiliate-related configuration centralized (e.g., base affiliate URL, campaign codes, or partner IDs).\n   - Allow easy extension to additional affiliate partners or link locations in the UI.\n\n2. **Click Attribution**\n   - Track when a user clicks a monetized (affiliate) link.\n   - Store minimal event data suitable for later analytics (e.g., what was clicked, when, and basic context).\n   - Ensure attribution logic runs reliably in a Blazor WebAssembly environment without breaking navigation.\n\n3. **Developer Experience**\n   - Keep all changes within `app/` (Blazor WebAssembly project).\n   - Provide simple, clear local run instructions in a root `README.md`.\n   - Log a summary of this monetization change in `logs/CHANGELOG.md`.\n\n## 3. Target Users\n\n- **End Users**\n  - Visitors using the Blazor WebAssembly app (e.g., browsing content or items the app presents).\n  - They may click on outbound or monetized links but should not face friction or confusing behavior.\n\n- **Internal Stakeholders**\n  - Developers and testers needing to understand and verify how affiliate links and attribution work.\n  - Product/marketing stakeholders interested in integrating affiliate programs and measuring performance.\n\n## 4. Key Features\n\n### 4.1 Affiliate Link Integration\n\n- Ability to render links in Blazor components that:\n  - Include affiliate query parameters or redirect through affiliate URLs.\n  - Accept parameters such as:\n    - Base destination URL (e.g., product or partner page).\n    - Affiliate ID or tag.\n    - Optional campaign code or placement label.\n  - Are visually similar to normal links unless explicitly styled differently.\n\n- Suggested technical behaviors:\n  - A small helper/service or component (e.g., `AffiliateLink` component or `IAffiliateLinkService`) that:\n    - Constructs final affiliate URLs from a base config.\n    - Is reusable across pages.\n  - Central configuration (e.g., appsettings-equivalent or a static config in `Program.cs` or a dedicated config class) for:\n    - Default affiliate ID / partner keys.\n    - Default campaign / channel identifiers.\n\n### 4.2 Click Attribution\n\n- When a user clicks an affiliate link:\n  - Record at least:\n    - A unique identifier for the link (e.g., product ID, partner name, or placement ID).\n    - Timestamp of the click.\n    - Basic context like page or section name, if easily available.\n  - Implement storage in a way suitable for WebAssembly:\n    - In-browser storage via JavaScript interop (e.g., `localStorage`) or\n    - In-memory tracking within the session (with awareness that it will clear on refresh).\n\n- Facilitate later export or inspection (for developers/testers) by:\n  - Either creating a simple debug view/page that lists recent tracked clicks, or\n  - Logging to the browser console with a clear and consistent format.\n  - The actual “reporting to server” is *not* required for this epic unless explicitly added later.\n\n### 4.3 UI Integration\n\n- Identify one or more existing pages in `app/Pages/` where affiliate links make sense (e.g., content detail, product listing, resources page).\n- Replace or augment existing outbound links with affiliate-enabled links.\n- Ensure:\n  - Normal navigation flow is preserved.\n  - The user is clearly navigating to another site if applicable (e.g., via standard link behavior or optional icon/text).\n\n## 5. Non-Goals (Out of Scope)\n\n- Full analytics pipeline or server-side event ingestion.\n- Complex consent management or cookie banners.\n- Dynamic external configuration from remote APIs.\n- Advanced fraud detection or bot filtering.\n- Multi-tenant/white-label affiliate configuration.\n\nThese may be added in future epics if needed.\n\n## 6. Technical Constraints & Notes\n\n- **Project structure**\n  - This is a Blazor WebAssembly project.\n  - All implementation changes must be within the existing `app/` folder:\n    - `app/Program.cs`\n    - `app/Pages/*`\n    - `app/wwwroot/*`\n    - Any additional files must be created under `app/` (not in a separate `frontend/` or `backend/` folder).\n\n- **No new frontend/backend split**\n  - Do **not** create new `frontend/` or `backend/` folders for the app UI.\n  - Keep to standard Blazor WebAssembly conventions.\n\n- **Local run instructions**\n  - The root `README.md` must clearly explain how to:\n    - Install prerequisites (e.g., .NET SDK version if known).\n    - Run the Blazor app via:\n      - `cd app`\n      - `dotnet run`\n    - Access the app in the browser (port description if standard).\n\n- **Logging / changelog**\n  - Update `logs/CHANGELOG.md` with a single, concise summary line describing:\n    - The date or version (if there is a convention).\n    - That affiliate URLs and click attribution were added/updated as part of EPIC 05: Monetization.\n\n- **Performance & UX**\n  - Click handling and tracking must not noticeably slow page navigation.\n  - Avoid blocking calls or long-running operations on click handlers.\n  - Degradation behavior:\n    - If attribution fails (e.g., local storage unavailable), the link should still navigate correctly.\n\n- **Security & Privacy**\n  - Do not include any secret keys directly in frontend code if real credentials are later introduced; use only demo/test IDs for now.\n  - Be cautious about sensitive user data:\n    - Do not record personal information in click attribution.\n    - Limit tracking to non-PII event metadata.\n\n## 7. Deliverables\n\n1. **Code & Config**\n   - Changes in `app/` implementing affiliate URL generation and click attribution.\n   - Any new components, services, or configuration required, placed appropriately in the Blazor WebAssembly project.\n\n2. **Documentation**\n   - `README.md` in the project root with:\n     - Brief project description.\n     - Setup requirements (e.g., .NET SDK).\n     - Clear instructions to run the Blazor app locally using `dotnet run` in the `app/` folder.\n     - Basic explanation of where monetization logic lives (files or namespaces).\n\n3. **Changelog**\n   - Updated `logs/CHANGELOG.md` with a summary line describing the monetization implementation for this epic.\n\n4. **Tests & QA**\n   - Test scenarios validating affiliate URL formatting, click attribution, and that navigation still works as expected.\n   - Manual/automated tests as defined in `TEST.md`.\n\nAGENT_TASKS.md:\n# AGENT TASKS – EPIC 05: Monetization\n\nThis file describes what each role needs to deliver for EPIC 05 within the existing Blazor WebAssembly project.\n\n---\n\n## 1. Frontend\n\n### Project Name\nEPIC 05 – Monetization (Affiliate URLs & Click Attribution)\n\n### Required Deliverables\n- Updated or new Blazor components/pages under `app/`:\n  - **Blazor components/pages** (examples, exact names to be chosen to fit existing structure):\n    - `app/Pages/<SomePage>.razor`:\n      - Integrate affiliate links into appropriate existing pages.\n    - (Optional) `app/Pages/AffiliateDebug.razor`:\n      - Simple UI for viewing recent click events, if this approach is chosen for debugging.\n  - **JS interop assets** (only if needed):\n    - `app/wwwroot/js/affiliateTracking.js` (or similar) to encapsulate any JavaScript needed for storage/logging.\n\n### Purpose of Deliverables\n- Render affiliate URLs in the UI and handle click events for attribution.\n- Provide optional, simple visualization or console logging of tracked clicks.\n\n### Key Technical Notes & Constraints\n- **Blazor WebAssembly only**\n  - All changes must live under `app/`; do not create `frontend/` or `backend/` folders.\n- **Pages & Components**\n  - Use existing layout and routing.\n  - Integrate affiliate links into one or more existing pages; avoid unnecessary new navigation endpoints.\n- **Click Handling**\n  - Use Blazor event handlers (`@onclick`) and/or JS interop to:\n    - Fire an attribution event.\n    - Then allow normal navigation to continue.\n  - Ensure event handlers are lightweight and non-blocking.\n- **Debugging**\n  - If a debug page is implemented, ensure it is:\n    - Clearly named and optionally excluded from production menus (or marked clearly as internal/debug).\n\n---\n\n## 3. Tester\n\n### Project Name\nEPIC 05 – Monetization (Affiliate URLs & Click Attribution)\n\n### Required Deliverables\n- Executed test cases and recorded results based on `TEST.md`:\n  - Verification of:\n    - Affiliate URL formatting.\n    - Click attribution behavior and storage.\n    - Navigation works as expected.\n    - README and CHANGELOG updates are correct.\n- Optional: A short internal note or checklist (not a required file) summarizing verification steps and outcomes.\n\n### Purpose of Deliverables\n- Confirm that monetization works functionally without degrading the user experience or breaking the build.\n- Ensure changes are documented and reproducible via the README instructions.\n\n### Key Technical Notes & Constraints\n- **Environment setup**\n  - Use instructions in root `README.md`:\n    - `cd app`\n    - `dotnet run`\n  - Confirm the app runs without errors from a clean environment (if possible).\n- **Functional checks**\n  - Validate that:\n    - Affiliate links include expected parameters (e.g., inspect via browser dev tools).\n    - Clicks generate attribution events (via debug page or console logs).\n- **Boundary checks**\n  - Confirm no changes outside allowed areas:\n    - No `frontend/` or `backend/` directory added.\n    - Only `app/` and `logs/CHANGELOG.md` and `README.md` in root are touched.\n- **Regression awareness**\n  - Sanity-check key navigation paths unrelated to monetization to ensure they still function.\n\ndesign/design_spec.md:\nEPIC 05 – Monetization (Affiliate URLs & Click Attribution)  \nDesign Specification (UI/UX)\n\n## 1. Scope & Intent\n\nThis spec describes how affiliate links and click attribution should appear in the existing Blazor WebAssembly app, without changing the overall layout or navigation structure.\n\n- Only touch existing pages/content where outbound or product/resource-style links already make sense.\n- Keep affiliate behavior mostly invisible technically, but make destination and intent clear to users.\n- Ensure any debugging/inspection UI for click attribution is clearly internal and not confusing for end users.\n\nBecause the exact existing pages and layouts are not specified here, this spec uses **generic page types** (e.g., “content/detail page”, “resources list”). Developers should map these patterns onto whichever real pages in `app/Pages/` are most appropriate.\n\n---\n\n## 2. UX Principles\n\n1. **Clarity over Surprises**\n   - Users should understand when they’re leaving the site or viewing a partner resource.\n   - Affiliate links should look like normal action/outbound links but use clear, honest wording (e.g., “View on partner site”).\n\n2. **Minimal Visual Noise**\n   - Do not add badges, labels, or marks that clutter the layout.\n   - Prefer short, descriptive link text. Avoid technical jargon such as “affiliate”.\n\n3. **Non-blocking Interaction**\n   - Click tracking must not delay or interfere with navigation.\n   - If tracking fails silently, the link still behaves like a standard link.\n\n4. **Separation of Concerns**\n   - End-user pages: clean, simple, and focused on content.\n   - Debug/inspection views: obviously internal and visually distinguished.\n\n---\n\n## 3. Primary User Flows\n\n### 3.1 Clicking an Affiliate Link on an Existing Page\n\n**Entry point**\n\n- User is viewing a page that presents items, content, or resources (e.g., a product, tool, or article detail).\n- Near descriptive text (title/summary), an action link appears such as:\n  - “Learn more”\n  - “View on partner site”\n  - “Check availability”\n\n**On-screen elements**\n\n- A text link or button-like link placed near the item title or summary.\n- The link visually matches existing outbound links (same color, typography), possibly with:\n  - Optional subtle cue for external site, such as:\n    - Text “(external)” appended in a lighter secondary style, or\n    - A small external-link icon, if already available in the design system.\n\n**Interaction steps**\n\n1. User reads item/content and spots a clearly labeled call-to-action link.\n2. User clicks the affiliate link.\n3. Click is tracked in the background (no visible delay or overlay).\n4. Browser navigates normally to the partner/destination page (same tab or new tab consistent with existing app behavior).\n\n**UX feedback**\n\n- Standard link hover and focus states apply.\n- No additional confirmation dialogs.\n- No popups or extra steps for users around the affiliate nature of the link.\n\n---\n\n### 3.2 Viewing Click Attribution for Debugging\n\nThis flow is intended for developers/testers, not typical end users.\n\n**Entry point options (one of):**\n\n- An internal/debug-only navigation entry (e.g., in a dev/test menu), or\n- A route that is reachable only by directly entering the URL in the address bar.\n\n**On-screen elements**\n\n- A simple, text-based layout (no heavy styling required) that includes:\n  - Page title: “Affiliate Click Debug” (or similar).\n  - Short note clarifying that this page is internal:\n    - Example text: “Internal debug view – shows recent affiliate link clicks stored in this browser.”\n  - A list or table of recent click records with:\n    - Link identifier (e.g., product/resource label or placement ID).\n    - Page or section where the click occurred (if available).\n    - Timestamp.\n  - Optional: clear message if no clicks have been recorded yet.\n\n**Interaction steps**\n\n1. Developer/tester navigates to the debug page.\n2. Any existing attribution events (e.g., this-session or recent) are presented in reverse chronological order.\n3. Developer can refresh the page to see updated events after performing new clicks on affiliate links elsewhere in the app.\n4. Key Features\n\n### 4.1 Affiliate Link Integration\n\n- Ability to render links in Blazor components that:\n  - Include affiliate query parameters or redirect through affiliate URLs.\n  - Accept parameters such as:\n    - Base destination URL (e.g., product or partner page).\n    - Affiliate ID or tag.\n    - Optional campaign code or placement label.\n  - Are visually similar to normal links unless explicitly styled differently.\n\n- Suggested technical behaviors:\n  - A small helper/service or component (e.g., `AffiliateLink` component or `IAffiliateLinkService`) that:\n    - Constructs final affiliate URLs from a base config.\n    - Is reusable across pages.\n  - Central configuration (e.g., appsettings-equivalent or a static config in `Program.cs` or a dedicated config class) for:\n    - Default affiliate ID / partner keys.\n    - Default campaign / channel identifiers.\n\n### 4.2 Click Attribution\n\n- When a user clicks an affiliate link:\n  - Implement storage in a way suitable for WebAssembly:\n    - In-browser storage via JavaScript interop (e.g., `localStorage`) or\n    - In-memory tracking within the session (with awareness that it will clear on refresh).\n\n- Facilitate later export or inspection (for developers/testers) by:\n  - Either creating a simple debug view/page that lists recent tracked clicks, or\n  - Logging to the browser console with a clear and consistent format.\n  - The actual “reporting to server” is *not* required for this epic unless explicitly added later.\n\n### 4.3 UI Integration\n\n- Identify one or more existing pages in `app/Pages/` where affiliate links make sense (e.g., content detail, product listing, resources page).\n- Replace or augment existing outbound links with affiliate-enabled links.\n- Ensure:\n  - Normal navigation flow is preserved.\n  - The user is clearly navigating to another site if applicable (e.g., via standard link behavior or optional icon/text).\n\n## 5. Non-Goals (Out of Scope)\n\n- Full analytics pipeline or server-side event ingestion.\n- Complex consent management or cookie banners.\n- Dynamic external configuration from remote APIs.\n- Advanced fraud detection or bot filtering.\n- Multi-tenant/white-label affiliate configuration.\n\nThese may be added in future epics if needed.\n\n## 6.
